title: Will the presidents of Russia and Ukraine meet in person before 1 August 2021?
possible_answers: Yes, in either Russia or Ukraine
Yes, somewhere other than Russia or Ukraine
preds: Putin is considering another annektation of an Ukrainian region and if he goes forward this weekend (during the Olympic games), a meeting in Russia might become imminent, by request of Zelensky, who isn’t a typical politician.
I don’t think Russia is interested in meeting and wouldn’t do so unless it was at an event in another country.
Putin has no interest in meeting
Window closed for this being plausible

On July 13, Kremlin spokesman reaffirmed that "no preparations are currently underway for a meeting between the two leaders": https://tass.com/politics/1313487
h/t @jayb
No. I do not see how Putin can gain by meeting Zelensky.
No signs currently of this happening by Aug. 1
Two weeks to go and no date or agreement of agenda.

Re-calibrating given closing window with prior assumptions RE: location of meeting holding. Small window of probability still open pending possible last minute crises that would compel a meeting to take place.

Putin questioned the value of meeting with Zelensky as he considers the Ukraine to be managed by the EU and the US.
While not refusing, Putin maintains that he wants to understand what there is to talk about.
As perhaps further provocation and an indication of a dislocation of relations between the two countries, the Ukrainian football team for the Euro 2020 tournament has a map of their country including the Crimea that has been annexed by Russia. Official military greetings are used as slogans on the shirt reading reads ‘Glory to Ukraine!’ and ‘Glory to the heroes.
It may only be football, but this is a competition showing on the world stage.
Russian foreign ministry spokesperson Maria Zakharova has described the slogans as echoing the Nazi rallying cries which is an emotive comment in Russia,

Knowing how fiercely anti-Russian the Ukraine President is, and given the direction the country has taken since 2014, along with Russia still having the upper hand in terms of the geopolitical situation, I doubt that Putin would decide to meet, and I doubt even more that Zelensky would want to see him.
No clear indications that this might happen soon.. https://tass.com/politics/1308811
Re-calibration given closing window of opportunity. Same assumptions from previous assessment

Putin does not see Zelensky as equal and won't be meeting him. In Putin's eyes, Zelensky is a clown, a stand-up comedian, vs Putin is a Tzar. Putin's culture is that by meeting Zelensky he gives Zelensky credibility.
Actually going up 10 more on no, a recent article says the Normandy Format talks being discussed are at the level of the foreign ministers, not the heads of state.

It sounds like they're discussing the end of July for the Normandy Format meeting. But that leaves very little wiggle room and there's lots of possibility for delay or for it to not happen at all. +23 on no

With Ukraine's Zelensky set to meet President Biden in July, it would leave little time to prepare for a meeting with Russia's Putin by August 1. Therefore my tally remains the same. However, I'm not certain how the tournament works, but if Ukraine were to play the Russian Federation in the World Cup, perhaps the heads of state would be forced to look at each from the sidelines, does that count as a meeting?  https://www.cnn.com/2021/06/07/politics/biden-zelensky-white-house-meeting/index.html
https://www.nytimes.com/live/2021/06/12/sports/euro-2020-live-scores

/Symbolic background: 2021 marks the 30th anniversary of the Ukraine's independence (as per referendum on 01 December 1991)
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_Ukraine#Independence /"Crimean Platform to end Russian occupation    ~ On September 23, 2020, Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky, who participated in the general debate of the 75th session of the UN General Assembly, called on partners to join an international platform for the end of the Russian occupation of Crimea.
   ~ In December 2020, Zelensky announced that the creation of the Crimean platform had already been backed by powers on both sides of the Atlantic.
   ~ The platform will operate at several levels. The first, the highest one, is the political level, which will involve heads of state and government. The second level is that of top diplomats and defense chiefs, the third is the inter-parliamentary level, and the fourth will involve non-governmental experts. An expert network will be created to enhance the effectiveness of government action, as well as engage additional intellectual resources in the platform's work.
   ~ The Crimean Platform summit is scheduled for August 23, 2021."
https://www.unian.info/politics/diplomacy-netherlands-to-participate-in-crimean-platform-summit-ukraine-independence-events-11449036.html

Recalibrating with a lower likelihood of the meeting occurring prior to 01 August (again continuing with the analytical lynchpin that Zelensky would logically seek to meet Biden prior to any meeting with Putin).  Zelensky and Biden due to meet at the White House sometime in July. This would leave only two weeks to cement logistics for the Zelensky and Putin meeting subsequent to the White House visit - indicating it increasing unlikely that a meeting between Zelensky and Putin will occur prior to the cut-off date.

Ukraine appear to be "choosing their side" in the face of some fairly ludicrous conditions for meeting from the Russian side: a move that will certainly annoy Putin who will only want to meet with his Ukranian counterpart from a position of strength. Ukraine finds itself in an awkward but also potentially advantageous tug of war between the US and Russia and with the US and Ukraine openly meeting and courting closer tiers, any bi-lateral between Putin and Zelensky before August 1st might be read as the diminutive Russian premier "courting" Ukraine's favour rather than commanding their government. Doesn't seem likely Putin would stand for such a presentation, so a meeting would need to take place against a back drop of punitive action taken by Russia (power outage or gas line shut down?) that would be seen as forcing Ukraine to come to the negotiating table from a position of weakness and meekness. A power shut down as 2021's winter kicks in would seem the most effective measure to take against Ukraine whilst stepping up military activity on and across the border.  Unlikely before 1st August 21.

It would seem that Moscow sets insuperable preconditions to meeting with Zelensky, which I cannot see how the latter could navigate before August 1. -----------------

The Nord Stream 2 pipeline seems to be well underway. Russia and Germany have ties between this. Russia and Germany also had ties with the Navalny extredition. Germany is going through a federal election and the leader will be decided in September. At that time would be a perfect opportunity to have a Normandy style meeting between Germany, France, Russia, and Ukraine, as proposed. Now if that also means it could happen sooner as a last get-together with German Chancellor Angela Merkel, that's also possible.
Revising upward.   There are a number of issues still to be discussed.

Favoring a meeting by a hair now, I'm seeing news articles talking about a "Normandy Format" meeting, which is apparently a meeting between the leaders of France, Germany, Russia, and Ukraine. I'll update more in the next week if more mainstream coverage of the possibility starts happening. A big question is even if they do this meeting if it will be scheduled before August 1. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Normandy_Format https://112.international/ukraine-top-news/macron-normandy-format-meeting-at-foreign-ministers-level-agreed-with-zelensky-putin-61841.html

After finding a recent article on the pre-conditions made by the Kremlin in regards to a Putin-Zelensky meeting, I've lowered my probability of them meeting by August 1. While public rhetoric and private discussions can greatly differ, it doesn't seem likely that Zelensky will adhere to the demands. Furthermore, with June 16 as the date for the Biden-Putin meeting there is a chance I guess that it could happen after that, but until a US ambassador to Ukraine is appointed, I don't think the US is giving a very encouraging vibe. And I don't see another force that could really push the two to engage, but I could be wrong. https://jamestown.org/program/one-on-one-with-putin-a-reckless-adventure-for-zelenskyy-part-two/

Source: https://tass.com/world/1296381 I'll assume for now that this references a possible meeting of lower-level government representatives, vs. heads of state.

"Speaking with Italian newspaper La Repubblica, Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky said that he believes the Vatican could be the best place for a meeting with Russian President Vladimir Putin.
'Yes, perhaps, this could be the best place from all points of view. The Vatican is truly an ideal place for dialogue about peace. The Holy See is a global moral authority that always acts effectively as a mediator, as it is impartial and it inspires trust among all parties to the conflict. That is why the Apostolic Capital has often been used in history to resolve conflicts between states and build a peaceful future,' Zelensky said."
https://angelusnews.com/news/world/how-realistic-is-the-idea-of-russia-ukraine-peace-talks-at-the-vatican/
Reassigning location of meeting, for a case of meeting as part of some other event.  But keeping the overall probability low.

Recalibration after the addition of a Biden-Putin meeting to Biden's European tour.  I still hold the analytic assumption that Zelensky should logically seek to meet Biden in person prior to meeting Putin. However, it is increasingly plausible that the precursor Biden-Zelensky meeting is held during this trip (or even factored into the EU or NATO summits).
Actually going up 5 on in Russia or Ukraine and -5 on elsewhere as the Donbas region has been floated.
Maintaining for now as it sounds like they are still tentatively discussing this.

Recent developments in the Russian supplied Nord Stream 2 pipeline to Germany have sparked renewed interest in a Putin/Zelensky meeting. The US is advocating against the deal, as it would bypass Ukraine and undermine European security. However, an olive branch of eased sanctions for the pipeline's CEO (a German) is in the works, as it could possibly dampen Russian reliance on Chinese investment. In my assessment, it "could" open the door for a meeting, if Germany or Europe were to put stipulations on Russia to acknowledge Ukrainian sovereignty before the gas turns on. Either way, the Russia/China/US triangle poses an interesting conundrum with Ukraine and Taiwan in similar "monkey in the middle" situations, likely to be made only more prominent as the Beijing-Kremlin relationship grows.  https://www.state.gov/nord-stream-2-and-european-energy-security/
https://www.cnbc.com/2021/05/20/dan-yergin-us-is-looking-for-a-way-to-peel-russia-away-from-china.html
Dmitri Trenin, the head of the Moscow Carnegie Centre, and always worth listening to, says that actually nothing happened in Reykjavik as the only thing they did was not shout at each other.
I don't feel a discussion is on the cards ywt
There is still ifs-ands-or-buts about location, time, and structure of meeting. I am also skeptical at the nasty rhetoric here and there.

There appears to be no movement on a Putin and Zelensky meeting, and with only vague assurances from the US, the chances of a meeting are slimmer. However, the strategic goals of Ukraine remain clear: attain a membership action plan from NATO and thus join the EU. Any concrete movement toward NATO would likely set off a hostile Russian response, and provoke some sort of action from NATO. Yet, many EU nations are apprehensive about permitting a nation into the group under tense conditions. I don't think NATO desires a true confrontation with Russia and thus the meeting will likely not take place because no one will be forcing it.

US is planning for a US-Russia summit this summer and the US president may also meet the Ukraine president during his Europe visit. Hence, there are chances that Ukraine may be in the agenda. 
If Russia agrees to include Ukraine in the agenda, then there is a possibility of high-level meetings leading to a presidential summit. 
All these series of events, if they happen, will take a long time and August is too short to see this.

Given current tensions & statements from both sides a meeting before the (still unconfirmed) US and Russian premier's bilateral seems incredibly unlikely despite Putin's claim that he' be happy to meet "any time" [1 and 2].  No signs of agenda agreement which seemed to be key to Zelensky's major achievements the last time these two met [3]. The aftermath of a bi-lateral (post June) seems very unlikely to bring about a substantial change in Russian behaviour towards Ukraine and so a meet between the Russian and Ukrainian sides still seems very likely to remain low before 1st August 21. A peace summit pushed for by the US in the wake of the bi-lateral is the only credible driver for a meeting it would seem, but even if this were to be achieved as an output of the bi lateral the arrangements for such a meeting would not seem likely to be resolved before the end of July. [2]  https://tass.com/world/1284377
[3]  https://www.nytimes.com/2019/12/09/world/europe/putin-zelensky-paris-ukraine.html

I believe it is highly unlikely that such a meeting will occur prior to 01 August.  Given Zelensky's overt desire for a NATO membership action plan, and the commitments from US officials regarding Ukraine's sovereignty in the face of recent tensions (e.g. Blinken's visit to Kyiv), Zelensky should logically seek to meet Biden in person prior to meeting Putin. This would send a strong signal before any eventual Biden-Putin or Zelensky-Putin meeting. However, the upcoming G7, EU and NATO summits in June would likely restrict such a bilateral to occur in the short-term, pushing the logical date for a Zelensky-Putin meeting out further than end of July. If a meeting are to occur, it seems unlikely that it would occur outside of Ukraine or Russia. Putin's dismissal of meeting Zelensky in Donbas region in favor of a potential meeting in Russia would tilt the scales towards the latter.

It seems as though both sides desire a meeting, but for different reasons. On Russia's behalf it's likely just for overtures in order to ease sanctions, while Ukraine seeks recognizable actions towards lowering tension. If they do meet, it will likely not be before August, and it will not be in Russia or Ukraine, but rather someplace mutually acceptable, without the possibility of external influence.

I'm not sure who benefits from a meeting in the next few months.  If anything Putin will want a show of force which precludes any meetings.
Wisdom of the crowd as anchor, adjusting up because i want it to happen.
In fact, I will adjust: same arguments, but even less weight on Zelensky actually doing it.

1) Putin will not meet in Donbass, because he claims Donbass rebels are independent from Putin
2) Putin will not meet anywhere other than Moscow, because he does not see Zelensky as equal. Zelensky needs to "come to papa" for Putin to be ok to meet
3) So the meeting only happens if Zelensky is willing to meet Putin on Putin's terms.
4) "Yes" for meeting is that it may be important from ego-perspective for Zelensky to be meeting Putin
5) "No" for meeting is because political pressure in Ukraine may be against meeting in Moscow
6) "No" is because Zelensky may be concerned that meeting in person will not help him achieve anything and not bringing a good outcome home will weaken his position Any Russia/Ukraine conversation that truly matters is Putin / Biden conversation

As @Ryan-Beck points out, there is evidence that Putin is willing to be diplomatic by the withdrawal of Russian troops. Then you factor in the fact that Biden and Putin are in the works of setting up a meeting this summer, given that both seem to be okay with the meeting taking place. Thus, there is a reasonable probability that Putin rides a wave of diplomatic meetings this summer and perhaps by August 1, 2021 - the closing date for this question. However, it is not clear I suppose that Putin has agreed to the meeting with Ukraine as quick as he agreed to the US meeting. If Zelensky maintains that Russia is a potential invador, perhaps the prospects of a meeting will die off and the Russians be put off by that rhetoric. So I guess these are some reasons to doubt that it would occur. HOWEVER, a virtual meeting is usually something to consider. And considering the fact that a four-way talk is on the table, and the previous meeting between the two happened in Paris and involved other countries, I do think there is a possibility it occurs outside of the two countries and the more likely option over bin 1 given the tension between Russia and Ukraine. Having one or the other in the other person's country just seems like a power struggle. But then again Trump stepped foot in North Korea. Anything is possible. https://www.france24.com/en/europe/20210416-russia-tensions-on-menu-as-macron-holds-talks-with-ukraine-s-zelensky
Putin want to use arms rather than words..

I think I'd be a little closer to 50-50 on whether they meet or not but hedging toward the crowd a bit. It seems like there's interest on both sides so I think there's decent weight on the possibility of a meeting, and Putin withdrawing troops makes it seem like willingness to be diplomatic may be real.

If the meet wouldn’t it be a major concession on the part of Ukraine? Perceptions of power:
Zelensky goes to Russia = Ukraine concedes to Russia
Putin goes to Ukraine = Ukraine not only conceded but makes it look like Russia wins
Meet on neutral territory = Ukraine concedes most positioning and doesn’t have the power to discuss things at home.
Lose, lose lose for Ukraine.  The political position is impossible at the moment.

The first questions to ask here is who would benefit from such a meeting and what is the end game.
Zelensky has suggested that he and Putin meet in Eastern Ukraine. Apart form the security issues, Putin holds the upper hand and would not acquiesce to such an arrangement.
Putin has stated that Volodymyr Zelensky is welcome in Moscow at any time, to discuss bilateral relations, but concerning the fighting in the Donbas region,  the Ukrainian President should first discuss the conflict with Denis Pushilin and Leonid Pasechnik who are the leaders of the two breakaway republics, Donetsk and Lugansk, to then discuss with third parties such as Russia.
This is somewhat disingenuous as Russia still considers the Ukraine to be a region rather than a sovereign country as it was one of the most important republics of the Soviet Union. "If President Zelensky wants to start repairing relations, then we of course welcome it," Zelensky looked for support and perhaps joining  the EU and NATO.  France's Europe Minister Clément Beaune stated that support is not the same as membership. EU foreign policy chief Josep Borrell said the bloc’s Foreign Ministers found the Russian build-up ‘very concerning’ but new sanctions were not envisioned against Moscow.
So, little support from them. An interesting perspective on Moscow’s eventual aims is made by Dr. Fabian Burkhardt. (Dr Fabian Burkhardt is a Research Fellow at the Leibniz Institute for East and Southeast European Studies in Regensburg. Before, he was an Associate in SWP's Eastern Europe and Eurasia division). Russia has issued 200,000 Russian Passports to Ukrainians from the “People’s Republics” of Donetsk and Luhansk that increases the difficulty of resolving territorial conflicts in the ex-Soviet Union by creating controlled instability that exerts pressure on Kiev. Burkhardt suggest this part of a greater plan to halt the decline of the Russian population. ‘By delaying any resolution to the conflict, Russia achieves two objectives simultaneously: it retains permanent influence on Ukraine via the Donbas, and it becomes more attractive to many Ukrainians as a destination for emigration’.
Burkhardt goes on to say that Russia’s aim is to torpedo any resolution of the conflict that by issuing Russian passports, pressure is exerted on the Ukraine by undermining its sovereignty without military annexation. This method known as mass extraterritorial naturalisation has been used in secession territories in Abkhazia, South Ossetia (both Georgia) and Transnistria (Republic of Moldova). Russia’s military build-up on the Ukrainian Border, being ostentatious and overt,  was possibly a signal from Putin that Moscow has red lines that will be written by them and not the West. Putin at his annual address to the Russian Parliament warned the US and NATO not to cross the red line on threat of  “ a swift, asymmetric and harsh response’ Therefore, in response to the question I will  suggest that Putin has nothing to gain from a meeting with Zelensky to discuss conflict in the Donbas, certainly holds the upper hand and is playing a long game. https://edition.cnn.com/2021/04/20/europe/ukraine-zelensky-putin-meeting-intl/index.html  https://www.themoscowtimes.com/2021/04/22/putin-offers-to-meet-ukraine-president-in-moscow-any-time-a73711

To be honest I doubt he will make any progress on ending the war as yesterday’s news underscored that the Kremlin is simply not interested as the conflict guarantees Ukraine can never join NATO, which can’t accept new members with an active border dispute according to its charter. Zelenskiy offered direct talks with Putin on Donbas and wants to revise the Minsk II deal.  Putin stuck to the fiction that Russia is an impartial observer (this point is enshrined in the Minsk II protocols) and that Zelenskiy needs to resolve the conflict with the rebel leaders in Donbas, not the Kremlin, but if he wants to go to Moscow for talks on improving bilateral relations he is welcome. This isn’t going anywhere any time soon.  bne news
Yes, summitry is the ‘new’ foreign policy tool of choice. Biden s invite to meet Putin was a stroke of genius. My 1% no represents an ‘act of God’ prevents it.

It appears that Ukraine's Zelensky is pushing for a meeting. (https://tass.com/pressreview/1283447, https://www.dw.com/en/ukraines-zelenskyy-hopeful-about-meeting-vladimir-putin/a-57339191)  They have met previously: https://www.nytimes.com/2019/12/09/world/europe/putin-zelensky-paris-ukraine.html  Putin supposedly is ready to meet "any time" in Moscow but has made no commitment: https://www.themoscowtimes.com/2021/04/22/putin-offers-to-meet-ukraine-president-in-moscow-any-time-a73711  At this point I don't think such a meeting is 'impossible'. E.g., Putin could agree to have (another) one primarily "for the sake of appearances".  FWIW: A meeting at the Vatican would seem unlikely..(https://tass.com/world/1284049)

Vlad the Shirtless has nothing to gain in either substance or atmospherics by such a shmoozefest, and he almost surely won't agree to an away game.  Zelensky, as the presumptive supplicant, would have to go to Moscow unless Putin graciously agrees to, say, Minsk.  That 82 is probably too low.
